message: @nickgassmann i wanted to know about wireframe..
i am new in UI/UX design. any mention about wireframing tool and ideas would help me. thanks.
Or Adobe Fireworks on OS X
+1 for Balsamiq, but I still prefer pencil and graph paper :)
Wireframe or UI sketch? I use Gliffy for wireframing, and Balsamiq if I don't feel like sketching out a UI.
@nickgassmann UI is a blurry term isn't it..
@bhu1st It's just more flexible than tools that are specifically design to make wireframes
@bhu1st I make boxes and labels.
@bhu1st That's the idea... depends on the client though :-)
I use mockingpad on ipad
@bhu1st Some people don't understand them and need to see high touch stuff to understand
If you're broke, or care a lot about open source, or need the file to be editable by *anyone*, try LibreOffice's Draw program. Similar to a slimmed down Visio.
If you're in a pinch, Google App's Drawing program isn't *horrible* and lets you easily share stuff. Other services do this too, but you probably already have a Google account.
@bhu1st I do, but they're just boxes in different shades of gray so not hard to manage.
@spencer how do you use fireworks for wireframing? i use fw just to design web pages.. never thought i could do wireframes in fw. i am in windows 7.
@spencer yeah..  i am trying to show wireframes to clients first before giving them design samples. if i could convince them with wireframes i think it will save some time later. what do you say ?
Balsamiq is a great option for 5-minutes wireframes. But, my option #1 is Fireworks.
@partlysean yeah I like to draw first then tweak usability on screen
Yea, so is blurry. :D
Then check out gliffy.
@bhu1st And wireframing is designing web pages, no?
@spencer agreed. but i am trying to deal with client this way for the first time. would say you later how it goes..  :D
@spencer plz tell me more about boxes and labels in fw. any good link to follow ?
@nickgassmann nice sample.. but that was more about sitemaps i think. i will try gliffy for sure... thanks
@bhu1st Good luck! Hope it works!
@spencer thanks.
maybe it's just me but wireframe != sketch != mockup in FW or PS
Gliffy is free and is built for wireframing.
@bhu1st I just mean I outline the site wireframe with boxes and sometimes I label them.. Just a completely stripped down black and white design.
Exactly. Work with what's easiest. In my case I just use what the application gives me: http://www.gliffy.com/publish/2064873/

thanks all for the input.. i am really new to this so one more query here, do you design all the UI element to use in wireframes by yourself ?? that should be a lot of work.. really.. how you manage that
You can find stencils for a few different programs here: http://iainstitute.org/tools/
they don't have to be exact... that's why they're wireframes.. that's how our workflow works anyway.
Otherwise yeah, make your own. Most designers have their own *feel*.
That's about as average as they come.
group i heard about pencil addon for firefox and have installed it.. its UI just scared me at first look... gliffy is really cool btw.
@bhu1st What do you think a wireframe is? It's a quick and easy way to structure a website without having to do a sketch. It allows you to map the architecture.
i would prefer you to go with Balsamiq.
https://gomockingbird.com/

One popular tool is Axure RP, which allows you to quickly produce code prototypes. It's pricey but has a great following. You might also want to checkout Todd Zaki Warfel's Prototyping book: http://rosenfeldmedia.com/books/prototyping/
@nickgassmann i was talking about http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Website_wireframe .. as far as i understand website sitemap is this : http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Site_map
@nickgassmann i found one here http://www.gliffy.com/examples/wireframes/
i will give some time to go through what you suggested here.. thanks group.
I really like balsamiq so +1 for that:) gomockingbird.com looks promising as a web app and thus maybe easier to share functional prototypes with clients, but then you have the monthly subscription...

For old school wireframes, I prefer Omnigraffle. As a desktop app, it's fast and configurable. Also has an array of templates and resources at Graffletopia.com. For clickable prototypes, Axure is pretty solid.
+1 for Balsamiq. Using for all my mockup needs... It's easy and fast.
I second Balsalmiq as well
Pen and paper all the way!!!
When it has to be digital, I go for OmniGraffle on Mac OSX
Pen & paper as @operator suggested :)

There isn't a need to just pick one. I use different tools for different projects and clients. I always start the brainstorming process with pencil and paper. Then when I'm polishing things up I use an app. For small and simple projects mockups for iPad works. For medium projects and more collaborative clients I use use mockingbird and for large projects that need very detailed annotations I tend to use omnigraffle. Sometime clients request I use Photoshop so often I use Photoshop. Also Keynote can be great tool too.
Chalk up another vote for Mockingbird
+1 for balsamiq
Omnigraffle #ftw
Expression Blend - Sketchflow is good for prototyping too.
iMockups for ipad
mostly omnigraffle; there are lots of free omnigraffle stencils here: http://graffletopia.com. mockingbird for quick sketches.
I've heard good things about balsamiq which integrates with Jira

Depends on how much fidelity your work requires. I always start with pen and paper then for if project requires high fidelity i use Omnigraffle if not any other flash based or iOS based apps are ok. Some use Keynote also but never tried.
If you're a Mac user, definitely try Keynote with templates from keynotekungfu.com
Pen+paper -> balsamiq -> HTML+CSS
Paper, OmniGraffle, Axure RP, sometimes Keynote
+1 Fireworks

@romanzolotarev same. Balsamiq is pretty great. I would use whatever wireframing tool which helps you keep the wireframe(prototype) in as low-resolution state as possible. Almost always two steps further backward than you think.
Balsamiq... or try this http://creonomy.com/2010/07/our-interactive-mockup-beamer-paper-and-tape/
Check http://gridpapr.com for quick sketching of ideas without going too much in details
Pen and paper (love Whitelines notebooks grid version for them) to Pencil (overlooked, but awesome and hackable tool) to html/css

Thanks all for sharing tools you use. I usually find myself sitting on Firefox for most web development works.. i managed to get familiar with Pencil plugin. It's awesome... you should try it once too.
Here are few pages i did with the Firefox Pencil add-on - http://bit.ly/j0IJEh http://bit.ly/jQZfWy
Does anyone just use illustrator or photoshop ... Creat simple editable symbols ... I guess it's not the same kind of thing though.
PowerPoint. You can make interactive prototypes in no time.
I used illustrator and put it into the invision app to share. It was ok but I think powerpoint and keynote would have done the same.
